review.title: From Propositional Logic to Plausible Reasoning: A Uniqueness Theorem
review.abstract: We consider the question of extending propositional logic to a logic of plausible reasoning, and posit four requirements that any such extension should satisfy. Each is a requirement that some property of classical propositional logic be preserved in the extended logic; as such, the requirements are simpler and less problematic than those used in Cox's Theorem and its variants. As with Cox's Theorem, our requirements imply that the extended logic must be isomorphic to (finite-set) probability theory. We also obtain specific numerical values for the probabilities, recovering the classical definition of probability as a theorem, with truth assignments that satisfy the premise playing the role of the "possible cases."

metadata.title: From Propositional Logic to Plausible Reasoning: A Uniqueness Theorem

sections.text: We look at the question of extending propositional logic to a logic of plausible thought and make four requirements that such an extension should meet, each of which is a prerequisite for maintaining a property of classical propositional logic in extended logic; as such, the requirements are simpler and less problematic than those used in Cox's Theorem and its variants. As in Cox's Theorem, our requirements imply that extended logic must be isomorphic to (finite) probability theory. We also obtain specific numerical values for probabilities and recover the classical definition of probability as a theorem, with truth assignments that meet the premise playing the role of "possible cases." Keywords: Bayesian, Carnap, Cox, Jaynes, Logic, Probability.

sections.heading: 9.1. The classical definition of probability
sections.text: The classical definition of probability dates back to Cardano in the mid-16th century [4, chapter 14]; perhaps his clearest statement was given by Laplace [15]: The probability of an event is the ratio of the number of cases that favor it to the number of possible cases, when there is nothing that would make us believe that a case should occur sooner than any other, so that these cases are equally possible for us. This definition fell out of favor with the rise of both frequentistic and subjective interpretations of probability. Theorem 14 takes us back to the beginnings of probability theory, which confirms and sharpens the classical definition. We can now say that a "possible case" is an assignment of truth that satisfies premise X. The formulation "these cases are equally possible for us," the definition makes the definition circular, can simply be dismissed as unnecessary.
